At that time, the TathÄgata Moon-like Realm told Bodhisattva Medicine King's Army:

You should know that all beings who have a body are suffering. Birth, old age, sickness, death, worry, distress, sorrow, pain, encountering what is hated, separation from what is loved, not attaining what is desired, and so forth, all these dharmas are suffering, oppressing beings and unable to be liberated.
This all-suffering is extremely frightening, yet beings do not hear or know about this meaning of suffering.
At that time, the newly born ones in the assembly, upon hearing the Buddha speak the names of these suffering dharmas, all joined their palms and said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
We delight in hearing about the meaning of this suffering. May the Buddha explain it for us.
The Buddha said:
Good men!
Not only you are happy to hear this, all sentient beings are also like this.
Those who were newly born said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
What is the meaning of death that you speak of?
The Buddha said:
Good men!
It refers to:
The extinction of consciousness and the disintegration of the body, which is called death.
When the life of all sentient beings is about to end, three kinds of winds come to destroy them, namely:
The wind that extinguishes consciousness, the wind that moves consciousness, and the wind that arouses consciousness.
When the life of sentient beings is about to end, these three kinds of winds cause the consciousness to disperse and extinguish, and the consciousness to move and change.
Those who were newly born said:
World-Honored One!
How can that wind that extinguishes consciousness cause the consciousness of sentient beings to extinguish and the body to disintegrate?
The Buddha said:
That wind that extinguishes consciousness is also of three kinds, namely:
Knives, needles, and great power.
Through these three, one can extinguish consciousness.
When consciousness is extinguished, the body will be destroyed.
The newly born ones said:
World-Honored One!
What is called a body?
The Buddha said:

The body is like an illusion, like a flame, like a heavy burden, and also like saliva, rotting things, and so forth. Those without wisdom cannot realize that birth is great suffering. Birth gives rise to, conditions the aggregation of dharmas, and sustains the life faculty, but it is not real, not associated with what is lovable. Such dharmas are provisionally called a body.
The newly born ones said:
World-Honored One!
What is called life?
What is called extinction?
The Buddha said:

That which is sustained by consciousness is called life. When the retribution of karma declines, the dharma of consciousness disperses, the life faculty is severed, and the parts of the body are destroyed, it is called extinction.
Good men!

I will now further explain the parts of the body for you. Know that in the human body, there are one koá¹­i of sinews and blood vessels, eighty-four thousand pores, one thousand two hundred branches and joints of the body, and three hundred and eight bones, which together form the human body;

There are also eighty-four thousand kinds of worms, such as these types of beings, which depend on the human body together. Day and night, they nibble and eat, and the worms also eat each other, and various sufferings arise.
Thus, among the eighty-four thousand kinds of worms, there are two large ones that fight each other for seven days and nights. On the seventh day, one worm dies, and then another worm fights with it.
When one worm dies, another worm is born. In this way, it continues until the human's life ends, and all these types of worms are destroyed and have no support.

Ordinary beings are unable to understand the arising and ceasing of the continuity of internal and external suffering, and are not afraid of old age, sickness, and death. They follow and oppose each other, fighting with each other, like two worms in the body, suffering arising with them. They are unable to understand that when the body perishes and life ends, everything becomes nothing.
Good men!
There is an ordinary being whose life is about to end.
A good friend comes to comfort him and asks him:
'In your present life, have you ever known or seen the hardships of birth, old age, sickness, and death?'
That person replies:
'I have known and seen them.'
The good friend says:
'Since you now know and see such sufferings, why don't you give rise to disgust and a superior mind?'

In the two worlds, planting few wholesome roots, cutting off all evil dharmas, and cultivating all correct practices. If one can do this, after abandoning this retribution, one will be born in a superior place, free from all fears, relying on wholesome dharmas.
How much more so for all the painful dharmas in the world, each and every one can be observed.
Have you not heard that if the great earth is struck, it can produce a great sound;
If wholesome dharmas are practiced, there is a greatly victorious power.

Therefore, in the pure lands of the TathÄgatas, plant various wholesome dharmas, namely, with flower garlands, ointments, food and drink, clothing, bedding, and medicine, make offerings to the TathÄgatas, and to the pure fourfold assembly of bhiká¹£us, bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s, upÄsakas, and upÄsikÄs. Making offerings like this is planting various wholesome seeds in the Buddha lands, which will be able to give rise to all wholesome fruits.
You have now encountered the great Dharma King appearing in the world. If you do not plant various wholesome roots, it will be of no benefit.
At that time, the good and virtuous friend spoke a verse to that ordinary person, saying:
The TathÄgata appears in the world, beating the great Dharma drum,
Opening the subtle Dharma door, causing all to enter.
Widely delivering all sentient beings, returning to the quiescent extinction of nirvÄá¹‡a,
You now see this matter, why do you not arouse diligence?
At that time, that person also spoke a verse, replying to the good and virtuous friend, saying:
If one is foolish and ignorant, and further encounters evil friends,
Extensively creating causes for defiled dharmas, namely greedy desires and so forth.
Giving rise to the view of self that becomes rampant, destroying the harmonious Saá¹…gha,
Damaging stÅ«pas and temples, not deeply believing in the Three Jewels.
But only creating various evil karma, not cultivating good causes and conditions,
At all times, always giving rise to various faults.
Disturbing and vexing parents, not giving rise to filial and respectful thoughts,
Uttering improper words, slandering and disparaging the virtuous and good.
Because of creating this evil cause, one will certainly fall into hell,
Personally experiencing a suffering body, with no one able to rescue and protect.
The terrifying combined hells, the hot hells, and the AvÄ«ci hell,
In these various hells, one will experience various sufferings in succession.
Emerging from these great hells, one will then enter the smaller hells,
Namely, the knife and sword hell and the lotus hell, experiencing suffering continuously.
In this way, the large and small hells, there are countless sentient beings,
Following their own karmic causes and conditions, experiencing heavy or light retributions.
Either a hundred eons, a thousand eons, or even longer,
Bound by the ropes of evil karma, there is no way to escape.
In that sword and weapon hell, a hundred yojanas long and wide,
One does not see the gate of that hell, only those who are suffering.
Hundreds of thousands of koá¹­is of sword trees and knives,
Driving those sinners to climb, their bodies are all cut and destroyed.
For a moment, though dead, they are again blown by the winds of karma,
Immediately they are reborn again, and experience various sufferings.
The hells have no boundaries, and sentient beings are also endless,
Because of the causes and conditions of evil karma, they continue without interruption.
I have created all kinds of evil karma, and will definitely fall into those realms,
Now, good and wise advisors, listen to the karma I have created.
I have once given rise to greedy thoughts, and extensively created dwellings,
Painted with colors and carved, adorned with gold and jewels.
I will not mention the various gardens, forests, warehouses, and businesses,
Or the cattle, horses, and other living beings that are all considered possessions.
Parents and relatives, both inside and outside the family, are very numerous,
With servants, maids, and entertainers, their number is limitless.
Always causing various songs to be sung day and night,
Only indulging in one's own pleasure, not thinking of the suffering of others.
Relying on that great wealth and nobility, various adornments are made,
All the objects of enjoyment are made of precious gold, silver, and jewels.
Washing with fragrant water, and applying various wonderful fragrances,
Including sandalwood, musk, and other such scents.
After washing with fragrant water, the body is then adorned in order,ğŸ”½With bracelets and finger rings all made of precious jewels.
With pearl necklaces, the neck is adorned,
The finest and best genuine gold, and also earrings and so forth.
Having adorned the body parts, one wears various wonderful flowers on the head,
Such as jasmine, champak, and various other fragrant flowers.
One also wears the most wonderful clothes, namely the finest and softest cotton,
Fresh, white, and clean, all with wonderful fragrances.
Food and drink of the finest flavors, sweet, delicious, and fragrant,
Attendants provide what is needed, without the slightest thought of hunger or thirst.
The ground is covered with fine carpets, and one treads on them as one goes about,
With attendants on the left and right, free and also noble.
Thus extensively adorned, one loves and delights in one's body,
Always cherishing and protecting it, without the thought of destruction.
Having already been fully endowed with wealth and pleasure, one has no further thoughts,
Giving free rein to one's defiled and lustful mind, creating unwholesome faults.
The eyes covet forms, and the faculties are also like this.
They are the causes of faults, and one cannot be aware of them oneself.
In the places of seeing, hearing, knowing, and perceiving, afflictions arise accordingly.
In relation to agreeable and disagreeable objects, the dharmas of greed, anger, and delusion arise.
Soft and other kinds of touch give rise to attachment in the mind and body.
Once the conception of attachment arises, all sinful actions are committed.
Once, without reason, I harmed sentient beings.
With an arrow I shot a deer's body, causing it to lose its life.
I only took its meat to eat, not thinking of the future,
that the fruits and retributions would naturally be received, and who could replace me.
I was foolish and ignorant, only nourishing my body.
One day, the suffering of death came, and consciousness ceased, the body decayed.
Only accumulating all kinds of suffering and distress, not a single lovable thought,
Parents and relatives, looking at each other, cannot save.
Good doctors, wonderful medicines, and so forth, are also in vain to set forth their efforts,
Only increasing the mind of sorrow and distress, without the means to rescue and help.
If my life is cut off, I will be abandoned in the charnel ground,
For birds, beasts, and insects, to be fully satisfied and eat.
All are nonexistent, illusory dharmas manifest before me,
All realms are completely empty, only the fruits and retributions are not lost.
At that time, having no place to rely on, only the good dharmas can be relied upon,
As I create evil causes, I will fall into hell.
Extensively accumulating the aggregates of evil karma, later suffering and distress arise,
In those three times, destroying the seeds of good dharmas.
The two dharmas of feeling and conceptualization, using various contacts as causes,
Because of contact, various cravings arise, forming the bonds of sorrow and suffering.
The good dharmas are like good medicine, able to cure the mind of craving and love,
When craving and so forth are no longer born, the various evils are unable to be done.
I truly have no blessings and wisdom, vainly receiving a human body,
The Buddha proclaims the gate of skillful means, giving, upholding precepts, and so forth.
I am unable to do them myself, I do not rejoice in seeing or hearing,
I am unable to listen to the true Dharma, my foolishness grows day by day.
Ignorance and other afflictions follow and turn without end,
Obstructing the causes and conditions of good dharmas, by what means can one attain liberation?
The deluded mind is scattered and disordered, without a moment of stillness,
Burned by the fire of afflictions, one undergoes various entanglements and bonds.
In the body there is not the slightest happiness, the joy of the Dharma does not arise for a moment,
When life is about to end, everything is destroyed.
Only the supreme Dharma of the Buddhas can save suffering sentient beings,
The gate of the true Dharma of precepts, those who ascend it attain great joy.
As for the karma I have created, I deeply regret it from the bottom of my heart,
Now encountering a good and virtuous friend, therefore I speak in accordance with the truth.
At that time, the TathÄgata of the Moon's Upper Realm told Bodhisattva Medicine King's Army:
Good man!

At that time, the Buddha then spoke a verse, saying:
Sentient beings who create evil karma will definitely fall into hell,
When hungry, they swallow iron pellets, and when thirsty, they drink molten copper.
Fierce flames emerge from their bodies, and due to evil karma, they burn themselves,
Their bodies are all destroyed, and they experience terrifying great suffering.
They do not see pleasant objects, nor hear the name of the true Dharma,
Only suffering oppresses body and mind, all is not loved.
Sentient beings who do good will definitely be reborn in a good realm,
Meeting with good spiritual friends, who encourage them to cultivate good dharmas.
Giving rise to correct faith and understanding, endowed with precepts, wisdom, and much learning,
Eliminating all afflictions, they will attain perfect enlightenment.
The practice of the highest conduct, proclaimed by the Buddha who has appeared in the world,
Stimulates all wholesome roots, not giving rise to discouragement.
Compassion is true spiritual practice, embracing all sentient beings,
Benefiting oneself and benefiting others, enabling them all to attain liberation.
Good man, listen attentively!
The Buddha's teachings are true, emitting subtle Dharma sounds, causing all to be tamed.
Great compassion is the father, the mind of enlightenment is the mother,
The good dharmas are friends, able to save and protect sentient beings.
The Perfectly Enlightened One appears in the world, expounding the supreme Dharma gate,
Skillfully transforming sentient beings, causing them to abide in the stage of quiescent extinction.
The Buddha is the one of great compassion, the most exalted World-Honored One,
Universally observing all sentient beings, equally regarding them as his Buddha-sons,
Equally without duality, causing all to take refuge.

World-Honored One!

I would rather use precious treasures, gold, silver, and crystal,

Then, those who had just been born spoke this verse:
